question_details.title: Will Virgin Galactic file for bankruptcy protection before 2026?
question_details.description:
This question is synced with an identical question on Metaculus. The original question opened on 2022-08-08 21:00:00 and can be found [here](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/12117). This question will resolve to the same value as the synced question. The original question's background info at this time is below. 

[Virgin Galactic Holdings, Inc.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virgin_Galactic) is an American publicly-traded spaceflight company founded by Richard Branson. The company is developing commercial spacecraft and aims to provide suborbital spaceflights to space tourists. 

The company went public through a SPAC merger in 2019, and reached a peak market capitalisation of over $14 billion [in February 2021.](https://ycharts.com/companies/SPCE/market_cap) However, since that time, the company's stock price has declined dramatically, falling more than 80% to less than $2.5 billion.

The company continues to burn cash, [losing over $100 million in Q2 of 2022,](https://investors.virgingalactic.com/news/news-details/2022/Virgin-Galactic-Announces-Second-Quarter-2022-Financial-Results-And-Provides-Business-Update/default.aspx) and recording revenue of just $357,000 in the quarter.

`{"format":"metac_closes_in_period","info":{"post_id":12117,"question_id":12117}}`
question_details.resolution_criteria:
This question resolves positively if Virgin Galactic Holdings, Inc. files any petition for bankruptcy protection in the United States, under any chapter of the United States Bankruptcy Code, before 1 January 2026. The question resolves on the filing of such a petition, not on whether any bankruptcy protection is granted by a court. The question resolves negatively if no such petition is filed by that date.

Only petitions filed by Virgin Galactic Holdings, Inc., or a renamed business entity comprising substantially all of Virgin Galactic Holdings, Inc.'s business (as judged by moderators) as of August 2022, will count towards resolution; any bankruptcy protection petitions filed by subsidiary entities or spin-off companies will not count

Virgin Galactic Holdings Inc (NYSE:SPCE) reported third-quarter 2025 financial results on November 13, 2025, highlighting progress in spacecraft manufacturing despite minimal revenue. Virgin Galactic remains on track for commercial operations in Q4 2026, with projections indicating that a fleet of two spacecraft and one launch vehicle could generate €450 million in annual revenue and €90–115 million in adjusted EBITDA. A larger fleet of four spacecraft and two launch vehicles could yield €990 million in revenue and €450–500 million in adjusted EBITDA. Management forecasts a cash flow range of -€90 million to -€100 million for Q4 2025, signaling a modest improvement in cash burn. The stock closed at €3.62, down 8.15%, reflecting investor concerns over the extended timeline to commercialization. Despite visible progress in spacecraft production, investor confidence remains cautious due to prolonged pre-commercial phase and continued capital needs.

**Virgin Galactic Is Delaying the Launch of Its Delta Spaceplane**
Virgin Galactic, a British American company founded by Richard Branson, is delaying the launch of its Delta spacecraft, which was initially set to debut in summer 2026. The company has paused all commercial operations since June 2024 and has reduced its workforce by 7% to focus on developing the upgraded spaceplane. Virgin Galactic reported a revenue of $410,000 in the second quarter, below analysts' expectations. The company plans to raise prices for ticket sales when they resume at the start of 2026, with prices expected to be higher than the current $600,000 per seat. Virgin Galactic is optimizing the spaceplane for reusability and faster turnaround time to compete with rival companies like Blue Origin and SpaceX.

**Virgin Galactic's Strategic Turnaround Pays Off**
Virgin Galactic has presented its quarterly results, showing a clear improvement in its loss situation. Despite a decline in revenue due to a temporary flight stop, the market is impressed by the company's consistent reorientation. The company reports a net loss of $67 million for the second quarter, a significant improvement from the $94 million loss in the same period last year. This success is based on drastic cost reductions, with operating expenses decreasing from $106 million to $70 million. However, the revenue fell short of analyst expectations, with only $0.4 million, compared to $4.2 million in the second quarter of 2024. The reason for this is the deliberate stop of commercial spaceflights in favor of developing the new Delta-Class spacecraft. Despite the strategic revenue decline, the financial situation remains stable, with liquid assets of $508 million. The company's operational cash flow improved from a loss of $79 million to a loss of $55 million. The progress in the Delta program gives reason for hope, with the wing and feather assembly of the new spacecraft expected to be completed this quarter, and the hull to be completed by early 2026. Virgin Galactic remains committed to its timeline for resuming commercial flights in the fall of 2026. The company is also exploring new business areas, including a possible partnership with the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory and the opening of a second spaceport in Italy. The market is rewarding the strategic reorientation, with the stock showing a robust performance despite short-term revenue declines. Investors seem to trust that the investments in the next generation of spacecraft will pay off in the long term.

summary: Across all expert perspectives—including corporate restructuring, bankruptcy law, venture capital, business administration, finance, and aerospace management—there is strong consensus that Virgin Galactic is unlikely to file for bankruptcy protection before January 1, 2026. The most heavily weighted reasons are the company's substantial cash reserves ($424 million as of September 2025), current quarterly cash burn of $90-100 million (providing runway well past the resolution window), and ongoing access to equity capital despite significant dilution. All experts acknowledge that Virgin Galactic is in deep financial distress, as evidenced by extremely poor Altman Z and Piotroski F scores, high leverage, and persistent negative margins. However, these indicators typically signal elevated medium-term rather than immediate bankruptcy risk—particularly for public, pre-revenue/high-burn technology companies that can continue raising capital. No expert identifies any imminent external catalyst (such as a major debt maturity, lawsuit, or regulatory action) that would force bankruptcy within the next 6 weeks. The base rate for companies in similar positions filing for bankruptcy in such a short period is cited as extremely low, and all agree that only a sudden, unanticipated, and catastrophic event would force a near-term bankruptcy filing. Final individual probabilities for a filing before January 1, 2026, are clustered between 2% and 7%. The collective outlook is that bankruptcy is possible but highly unlikely in the immediate term, though long-term viability remains deeply questionable.
